haenyeo-of-jeju-1.title: Haenyeo of Jeju
haenyeo-of-jeju-1.description: Haenyeo (also spelled haenyo) (Hangul: 해녀; lit. sea women) are female divers in the Korean province of Jeju. All together, the tools of a haenyeo consist of a wetsuit, goggles, gloves, chest weights (to assist diving) an L-shaped weeding hoe, and a net attached to a flotation device. The haenyeo stash their catch in these nets until they are done for the day. With each dive, haenyeo plunge up to 30 meters deep and can hold their breath for over three minutes. Image collect by Underwater Earth / Christophe Bailhache.

jeju-island-biosphere-reserve.title: Jeju Island Biosphere Reserve
jeju-island-biosphere-reserve.description: Situated in the Seogwipo coast, Munseom, Beomseom, and Seopseom Islets are uninhabited and designated as National Nature Reserves. Rare species including the Silver Mangolia and Japanese Black Wood Pigeons are found especially on Munseom and Beomeom. Asplenium antiquum grows only on Seopseom. Not only diverse flora, but soft coral communities are also well-known around there. Warm currents support subtropical fish in these waters all year round, and sometimes newly and non-registered marine species come in, as well. Image collect by Underwater Earth / Christophe Bailhache.

jeju-island-biosphere-reserve-2.title: Jeju Island Biosphere Reserve
jeju-island-biosphere-reserve-2.description: Situated in the Seogwipo coast, Munseom, Beomseom, and Seopseom Islets are uninhabited and designated as National Nature Reserves. Rare species including the Silver Mangolia and Japanese Black Wood Pigeons are found especially on Munseom and Beomeom. Asplenium antiquum grows only on Seopseom. Not only diverse flora, but soft coral communities are also well-known around there. Warm currents support subtropical fish in these waters all year round, and sometimes newly and non-registered marine species come in, as well. Image collect by Underwater Earth / Christophe Bailhache.

coral-gardens-palmyra-atoll-usa.title: Coral Gardens, Palmyra Atoll, USA
coral-gardens-palmyra-atoll-usa.description: Snorkeling here is the best way to see the brilliantly colored corals at Palmyra Atoll. Biologists have known for decades that corals have symbiotic algae in their tissue called zooxanthellae that give the corals color. However, recent studies have shown that corals also get color from pigmented proteins that act as a natural sunscreen for the coral. The shallower the water, the more UV protection is needed and the brighter the coral. This makes Coral Gardens one of the prettiest reefs at Palmyra. Image collect by Underwater Earth / The Ocean Agency / Christophe Bailhache.

crazy-corals-palmyra-atoll-usa.title: Crazy Corals, Palmyra Atoll, USA
crazy-corals-palmyra-atoll-usa.description: Crazy Corals is named for the amazing diversity of coral shapes found at the site. Corals can form different shapes depending on the environment where they live. The same species may be flattened against the bottom in a high energy surf zone, be shaped like a column in a channel with moderate current flow, or form giant elevated tables in a calm inner lagoon. Crazy Corals is one of the more protected sites at Palmyra Atoll, which allows the corals to grow into shapes that would never survive in other locations. Image collect by Underwater Earth / The Ocean Agency / Christophe Bailhache.

eastern-terrace-palmyra-atoll-usa.title: Eastern Terrace, Palmyra Atoll, USA
eastern-terrace-palmyra-atoll-usa.description: The Eastern Terrace is a harsh place, both for corals and divers, due to strong trade winds from the northeast. Ocean currents create areas of nutrient upwelling here, so when the wind does die down and divers can access the site, they are treated to huge schools of baitfish feeding on clouds of plankton. Black tip and grey reef sharks are also abundant, often hanging out in the middle of the baitfish. Image collect by Underwater Earth / The Ocean Agency / Christophe Bailhache.

holei-palmyra-atoll-usa.title: Holei, Palmyra Atoll, USA
holei-palmyra-atoll-usa.description: The reefs at Holei drop quickly from the crashing surf break to the deep ocean depths, with a shallow shelf between the two. Sharks cruise by in the blue, and schools of snapper and barracuda hang out along the narrow ledge. Whilst this is a great spot to watch large predators, there are also plenty of smaller creatures to be found amongst the corals. It’s a constant battle between focusing on the small stuff and watching out for the next shark! Image collect by Underwater Earth / The Ocean Agency / Christophe Bailhache.

jurassic-park-palmyra-atoll-usa.title: Jurassic Park, Palmyra Atoll, USA
jurassic-park-palmyra-atoll-usa.description: Nowhere at Palmyra Atoll do you see more action than Jurassic Park! This western site is where currents that flow along the north and south sides of the island meet. When conditions are right you can find huge schools of baitfish, jacks, milkfish, and sharks that come to this site to feed. Look out for the grey reef sharks! Image collect by Underwater Earth / The Ocean Agency / Christophe Bailhache.

mega-jacks-palmyra-atoll-usa.title: Mega Jacks, Palmyra Atoll, USA
mega-jacks-palmyra-atoll-usa.description: Mega Jacks is known for its schooling fish, but the site also has a healthy coral reef that is home to a wider variety of fish. Schools of big eyed jacks (Caranx sexfasciatus), blue trevallies (Caranx melampygus), and red snappers (Lutjanus bohar) often hang mid-water. Manta rays and sharks swim along the offshore ledge. And large schools of humpback snapper (Lutjanus gibbus) hug the reef, mixed with swarms of colorful anthias. Image collect by Underwater Earth / The Ocean Agency / Christophe Bailhache.

melon-headed-whales-palmyra-atoll-usa.title: Melon headed whales, Palmyra Atoll, USA
melon-headed-whales-palmyra-atoll-usa.description: If you head offshore of Palmyra Atoll you often find the resident pod of melon headed whales (Peponocephala electra). Hundreds of individuals can be seen in the pod, resting during the day in the deep waters around the atoll. Things change at night, when the pod becomes much more active as it feeds on squid that rises close to the surface. Image collect by Underwater Earth / The Ocean Agency / Christophe Bailhache.

penguin-spit-palmyra-atoll-usa.title: Penguin Spit, Palmyra Atoll, USA
penguin-spit-palmyra-atoll-usa.description: Once considered one of the most beautiful coral reefs at Palmyra Atoll, Penguin Spit has been taken over by the corallimorph Rhodactis howesii.  This invasion highlights one of the greatest threats to these reefs. Scientists believe that a boat that ran aground on a nearby reef is responsible for the outbreak, either by bringing the first corallimorphs to Palmyra Atoll, or by supplying iron, a nutrient that promotes corallimorph growth over corals. Image collect by Underwater Earth / The Ocean Agency / Christophe Bailhache.

the-channel-palmyra-atoll-usa.title: The Channel, Palmyra Atoll, USA
the-channel-palmyra-atoll-usa.description: Palmyra Atoll was a strategic military outpost for U.S. troops, aircraft, and ships on their way to the South Pacific during World War II. However, there was no way for warships to get into the atoll until the military dredged a large deep channel into the western lagoon.  Spoils from the channel were used to build a runway and four new islands.  Today the channel is primarily used by sharks, manta rays, and turtles to move in and out of the atoll. See which you can spot in this virtual dive! Image collect by Underwater Earth / The Ocean Agency / Christophe Bailhache.

nishibama-aka-island-okinawa-japan.title: Nishibama, Aka Island, Okinawa, Japan
nishibama-aka-island-okinawa-japan.description: Nishibama beach on the island of Akajima is a fantastic place to jump in for a snorkel or scuba dive. Coral bommies are bursts of colour and activity against the sandy bottom, with clouds of colourful reef fish darting above. Image collect by Underwater Earth / The Ocean Agency / Christophe Bailhache.

komodo-islands.title: Komodo Islands
komodo-islands.description: Komodo Island is home to the world's largest lizards, the Komodo Dragon. The initial drive to protect the region of Komodo was to protect the “living dinosaur” that makes these arid islands home. In 1986 it was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a Man and Biosphere Reserve that now encompasses all the biodiversity of the area, marine, terrestrial and cultural.

yonaguni-monument-yonaguni-okinawa-japan.title: Yonaguni Monument, Yonaguni, Okinawa, Japan
yonaguni-monument-yonaguni-okinawa-japan.description: Submerged rock formations at Yonaguni have mystified scholars for many years. Some believe the formations are natural phenomena and others argue there is evidence that they are manmade, the remains of a fabled Pacific civilisation which vanished into the ocean. Either way, it is a fascinating dive site with very strong currents. Image collect by Underwater Earth / The Ocean Agency / Christophe Bailhache.

giant-potato-nagura-bay-ishigaki-okinawa.title: Giant Potato, Nagura Bay, Ishigaki, Okinawa, Japan
giant-potato-nagura-bay-ishigaki-okinawa.description: Nagura bay is famous for being home to a huge Pavona Clavus coral, considered the largest coral ever found in Japan. The coral colony is shaped like a mountain with the peak at a depth of two to three meters and the deepest section at 13 meters, with a circumference of about 70 meters. Image collect by Underwater Earth / The Ocean Agency / Christophe Bailhache.

yamada-point-onna-okinawa-japan.title: Yamada Point, Onna, Okinawa, Japan
yamada-point-onna-okinawa-japan.description: The coral transplantation area at Yamada Point is the largest of its kind in the world, covering three hectares. It is part of a project to protect and restore coral reefs that are under threat. Image collect by Underwater Earth / The Ocean Agency / Christophe Bailhache.

aharen-beach-tokashiki-okinawa-japan.title: Aharen Beach, Tokashiki, Okinawa, Japan
aharen-beach-tokashiki-okinawa-japan.description: Tokashiki is the largest of the group of Kerama Islands and is the most heavily populated. The island is well known for diving, snorkelling and other marine sports. Aharen Beach is the place to go - a white curved beach stretching for 800 metres with impressive coral reef gardens in the clear waters just off shore. Image collect by Underwater Earth / The Ocean Agency / Christophe Bailhache.

agariushi-gahi-island-zamami-okinawa-jap.title: Agariushi / Gahi Island, Zamami, Okinawa, Japan
agariushi-gahi-island-zamami-okinawa-jap.description: Zamami Island is the second biggest island in the group of some 20 Kerama Islands. The majority of visitors to this island are divers, who come to experience the fields of corals and kaleidoscope of colourful reef fish. Image collect by Underwater Earth / The Ocean Agency / Christophe Bailhache.

taketomi-south-shark-home-taketomi-okina.title: Taketomi-south Shark Home, Taketomi, Okinawa, Japan
taketomi-south-shark-home-taketomi-okina.description: Taketomi is a small island known for its white sand beaches, 4 kilometres (2.5 miles) south of Ishigaki Island. It is also a prime spot for scuba diving. The intricate coral reefs and myriad marine creatures found here act as compelling evidence. Image collect by Underwater Earth / The Ocean Agency / Christophe Bailhache.

milky-way-submarine-sekisei-lagoon-ishig.title: Milky Way / Submarine, Sekisei Lagoon, Ishigaki, Okinawa, Japan
milky-way-submarine-sekisei-lagoon-ishig.description: Sekisei Lagoon is the largest coral reef sea in Japan and is a very popular diving site. However, corals in the Lagoon are under stress from terrestrial runoff, coral bleaching, and crown-of-thorns starfish outbreaks. Japan has been focused on restoring this reef through coral transplants and addressing the cause of the degradation. Image collect by Underwater Earth / The Ocean Agency / Christophe Bailhache.

cape-kri-raja-ampat-indonesia.title: Cape Kri, Raja Ampat, Indonesia
cape-kri-raja-ampat-indonesia.description: Raja Ampat is Indonesia’s most easterly province and has earned its reputation as the world epicentre of marine biodiversity. At Cape Kri the tremendous amount of fish life is dominated by dogtooth tuna, giant trevallies, and chevron barracuda. The coral growth here is equally fantastic, with numerous hard and soft varieties. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

tatawa-kecil-komodo-indonesia.title: Tatawa Kecil, Komodo, Indonesia
tatawa-kecil-komodo-indonesia.description: Tatawa Kecil is a small island south of Tatawa Besar Island, with spectacular underwater rock formations, caves and beautiful coral gardens known for fantastic snorkelling. The crystal clear reef shallows are teeming with life and display vibrant and colourful varieties of hard coral. The area is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a Man and Biosphere Reserve. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

batu-bolong-komodo-indonesia.title: Batu Bolong, Komodo, Indonesia
batu-bolong-komodo-indonesia.description: Widely considered to be one of Komodo’s best dive sites, Batu Bolong is a rock pinnacle that lies between Tatawa Island to the east and Komodo main island to the west. The currents here can be very strong, but that is what has protected the site. The reef is covered with every form of marine life imaginable, with swirling clouds of brilliantly coloured reef fish, numerous species of corals, and larger fish cruising along. The area is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a Man and Biosphere Reserve. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

keruo-raja-ampat-indonesia.title: Keruo, Raja Ampat, Indonesia
keruo-raja-ampat-indonesia.description: Raja Ampat is famous for its healthy reefs and world-record marine biodiversity. The picturesque coral garden at Keruo is no exception, with a kaleidoscope of colourful corals and bright reef fish darting around the reef. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

canal-da-sela-ginete.title: Canal da Sela Ginete
canal-da-sela-ginete.description: Spinner Dolphins are small dolphins famous for their spinning, acrobatic aerial displays. During the day these creatures rest in the shallow bays of Fernando de Noronha and then move into deeper waters around dusk to hunt. Imagery collected by the XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

drop-off-tulamben-bali-indonesia.title: Drop-off, Tulamben, Bali, Indonesia
drop-off-tulamben-bali-indonesia.description: On the way to Tulamben’s Drop-Off dive site in Bali, there is often plenty of fish action to be encountered in the shallows, such as these Giant Trevally, schooling Big Eye Trevally and Yellowstripe Scad. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

leukan-iii-b-bunaken-national-park-indon.title: Leukan III B, Bunaken National Park, Indonesia
leukan-iii-b-bunaken-national-park-indon.description: Bunaken National Park is home to some of the highest levels of biodiversity in the world. Oceanic currents sweep past Bunaken Island bringing a steady supply of nutrients to the marine ecosystem. The steep walls here have tremendous coral growth with bustling fish life and many turtles to be found. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

timor-ii-bunaken-national-park-indonesia.title: Timor II, Bunaken National Park, Indonesia
timor-ii-bunaken-national-park-indonesia.description: Timor is one of the most popular diving spots in Bunaken National Park. The near-vertical wall of coral stretches along the entire east coast of Bunaken Island. Look out for turtles resting beneath overhangs in the reef. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

leukan-iii-a-bunaken-national-park-indon.title: Leukan III A, Bunaken National Park, Indonesia
leukan-iii-a-bunaken-national-park-indon.description: Bunaken National Park is home to some of the highest levels of biodiversity in the world. Oceanic currents sweep past Bunaken Island bringing a steady supply of nutrients to the marine ecosystem. The steep walls here have tremendous coral growth with bustling fish life and many turtles to be found. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

fukui-bunaken-national-park-indonesia.title: Fukui, Bunaken National Park, Indonesia
fukui-bunaken-national-park-indonesia.description: Unlike most of the Bunaken diving locations, Fukui is not a steep wall, but more of a slope with a few short drops. Intricate coral reefs are interspersed with flat sandy patches home to garden eels. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

bangka-island-indonesia.title: Bangka Island, Indonesia
bangka-island-indonesia.description: Bangka Island lies off the northern tip of Sulawesi. The island is quite exposed and often gets strong currents, which can come from all directions. Underwater there are steep pinnacles with fantastic colourful corals, attracting scuba divers from all over the world. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

alung-banua-bunaken-national-park-indone.title: Alung Banua, Bunaken National Park, Indonesia
alung-banua-bunaken-national-park-indone.description: Alung Banua is a coral reef wall with many cracks and crevices between the numerous species of hard coral. Come for a virtual dive and spot a turtle or two. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

panggulingan-manado-tua-island-bunaken-n.title: Panggulingan, Manado Tua Island, Bunaken National Park, Indonesia
panggulingan-manado-tua-island-bunaken-n.description: Above water, Manado Tua Island is a magnificent extinct volcano rising over 600 metres above sea level. Underwater, there are rich coral gardens sloping from 5 metres to 30 metres, fringed by vertical coral walls plunging to 50 metres down. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

buraco-do-inferno.title: Buraco do Inferno
buraco-do-inferno.description: Fernando de noronha has many blow holes like this one called "The Devils hole". When the tide is right, the blow hole releases air from the roof of a sub-surface cavernin a dramatic, explosive display. You can see the blow hole erupting in this virtual dive. Image collected by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

minke-whales-on-the-ribbon-reef.title: Minke Whales on the Ribbon Reef
minke-whales-on-the-ribbon-reef.description: Dwarf Minke Whales travel through the Great Barrier Reef each winter where specialist dive operators and researchers wait to meet them. In 2014 the Catlin Seaview Survey team joined a Mike Ball expedition to track the whales.

galapagos-islands-ecuador.title: Galápagos Islands, Ecuador
galapagos-islands-ecuador.description: Inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage list in 1978 and situated in the Pacific Ocean some 1,000 km from the South American continent, these 19 islands and the surrounding marine reserve are referred to as a unique ‘living museum and showcase of evolution’. Located at the confluence of three ocean currents, the Galápagos are a ‘melting pot’ of marine species, this dive features the playful Galápagos sea lions by Isla Campion (Champion Island). Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey in partnership with Charles Darwin Foundation and Galápagos National Park.

shelly-beach-australia.title: Shelly Beach, Australia
shelly-beach-australia.description: Shelley Beach is a protected marine area (part of Cabbage Tree Bay) which was declared a "No Take" Aquatic Reserve in 2002. Since being listed as a protected area local scuba divers and snorklers say they are seeing an increase in marine creatures here - a great observation. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

devils-crown-galapagos.title: Devil's Crown, Galapagos
devils-crown-galapagos.description: The Devil's Crown is located off the northeast shore of Floreana Island, Galapagos. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey in partnership with Charles Darwin Foundation and Galapagos National Park. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

crystal-bay-indonesia.title: Crystal Bay, Indonesia
crystal-bay-indonesia.description: Mola mola (a.k.a Ocean Sunfish) are the heaviest bony fish in the world, with adults weighing up to 2,000 kg. They can measure 3 metres in length and 4 metres from tip to tip. These elusive giants are generally solitary and pelagic, spending much of their time at depth ranging from 200-600 metres. However, for a few months of the year they visit the reefs around Nusa Penida, and can be seen coming up from the deep to bask at the surface. There is still little we know about these amazing creatures. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

nudis-retreat-indonesia.title: Nudi's Retreat, Indonesia
nudis-retreat-indonesia.description: Nudi’s Retreat gets its name from the large variety of nudibranchs that can be found at this popular dive site. There are plenty of other marine creatures as well, with a healthy and diverse coral reef bursting with life and colour. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

champion-island-east-galapagos.title: Champion Island East, Galápagos
champion-island-east-galapagos.description: Champion is a small island located very near Floreana island, where a diver can find schools of fish and sea turtles. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey in partnership with Charles Darwin Foundation and Galápagos National Park.

da-bai-sha-green-island-taiwan.title: Da Bai Sha, Green Island, Taiwan
da-bai-sha-green-island-taiwan.description: Da Bai Sha is one of the most popular snorkeling spots on Green Island. When you jump in from the jetty and swim out to view the colorful coral gardens and coral pinnacles, you can see why. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

three-rock-green-island-taiwan.title: Three Rock, Green Island, Taiwan
three-rock-green-island-taiwan.description: Green Island is a lush, volcanic island off the south east coast of Taiwan. It has become a centre for recreational scuba diving in Taiwan with warm waters and roughly 300 species of hard coral to be seen. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

hong-chai-kenting-national-park-taiwan.title: Hong Chai, Kenting National Park, Taiwan
hong-chai-kenting-national-park-taiwan.description: Kenting National Park lies on Taiwan’s southern tip. Established in 1984, it is Taiwan’s oldest national park. The subtropical climate here allows a variety of marine life to flourish, including over a thousand species of fish and 60% of the world’s coral species. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

dongji-habor-dongji-island-taiwan.title: Dongji Habor, Dongji Island, Taiwan
dongji-habor-dongji-island-taiwan.description: Dongji Harbour was a major transition hub for traditional fishery in the Taiwan Strait several centuries ago, however most residents left after the fishing industry here declined in 1970s. In 2014, Dongji became a Marine National Park and now fishing is completely banned to protect the ecosystem. There is still much coral life to be seen here – including some bright red Lobed Brain Corals! Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

nuclear-outlet-kenting-national-park-tai.title: Nuclear Outlet, Kenting National Park, Taiwan
nuclear-outlet-kenting-national-park-tai.description: This area is particularly interesting because it is the only coral reef next to a Nuclear Power Plant in the world. This means the average water temperature is 2-3°C higher than other reef sites in the area and scientists can study the effects of thermal stress on the corals. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

emilys-pinnacles-bermuda.title: Emily's Pinnacles, Bermuda
emilys-pinnacles-bermuda.description: Impressive hard coral formations found here provide the building blocks for the reef. Imagery collected by Catlin Seaview Survey.

rarotonga-cook-islands.title: Rarotonga, Cook Islands
rarotonga-cook-islands.description: The whole 2 million square kilometre exclusive economic zone of the Cook Islands is a designated whale sanctuary. During May and October every year the Humpback Whales arrive in the Cook Islands. They are migrating north to South Pacific waters from their summer feeding grounds of Australia, New Zealand, and the cool Antarctic Ocean. They use these warmer waters to mate, give birth and to rest. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

muli-kandu-maldives.title: Muli Kandu, Maldives
muli-kandu-maldives.description: Found on the outer edge of Meemu Atoll, this large channel attracts an abundance of fish, including Oriental Sweetlips, Clown Triggerfish, and Longfin Bannerfish. The north section of Muli is a breeding ground for turtles, which can often be seen cruising in the current. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

the-liberty-wreck-bali.title: The Liberty Wreck, Bali
the-liberty-wreck-bali.description: The USAT Liberty was a 120m long ex-American cargo ship which now rests just off a rocky Tulamben beach in the northeast of Bali. The Liberty was torpedoed by a Japanese sub in the Lombok Strait in 1942 but wasn't sunk, it made it to Tulamben where it remained beached until 1963. When Mt Agung erupted in 1963 the associated earth tremours pushed the vessel out into the sea where it rests today. The coral covered wreck is one of Bali's most popular dives and it provides habitat for all manner of marine creatures. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

batu-rufus-indonesia.title: Batu Rufus, Indonesia
batu-rufus-indonesia.description: With 600 species of coral and more than 1,300 species of coral reef fish, Raja Ampat has the highest level of marine biodiversity in the world. Take a virtual dive to experience this underwater richness at the beautiful sloping coral garden of Batu Rufus, leading to a swim-through arch. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

big-momma-american-samoa.title: Big Momma, American Samoa
big-momma-american-samoa.description: Its true name is “Fale Bommie” (in honor of Fale Tuilagi who discovered it), but "Big Momma" is the nickname local divers have given this huge Porites coral, which may well be the largest coral on the planet. It is 41 metres in circumference and 7 metres high. This type of ‪‎coral grows very slowly, as little as 1 centimetre a year, which means that this coral is over 500 years old! Big Momma is located in the aptly named "Valley of the Giants" within the National Marine Sanctuary of American Samoa. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

airport-reef-american-samoa.title: Airport Reef, American Samoa
airport-reef-american-samoa.description: These are the very first 360° images ever taken of a coral bleaching event and documenting the death of a reef due to climate change. They reveal the transition of a reef in American Samoa, from healthy in 2014, to bleached and then dead in 2015, during the 3rd Global Coral Bleaching Event. These events are a new phenomena caused by climate change and our rapidly warming oceans (93% of global warming heat is absorbed by the ocean). The first global event in 1998 killed an estimated 16% of the world's corals. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

nelson-island-outside-chagos.title: Nelson Island Outside, Chagos
nelson-island-outside-chagos.description: At this remote island in the northern Chagos archipelago, table corals of varying forms provide an integral coral reef habitat for a variety of reef fishes. Curious tawny nurse sharks and black trevallies swim by, but can sometimes be difficult to spot through the clouds of bait fishes obscuring the water column. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

tafeu-cove-american-samoa.title: Tafeu Cove, American Samoa
tafeu-cove-american-samoa.description: American Samoa is a string of seven remote islands in the South Pacific, 2,500 miles south of Hawaii. There are extensive coral reefs here, rich in marine life. This virtual dive, within the National Park of American Samoa, starts as a half-in / half-out and then dives underwater for a virtual tour of the reef. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

whale-sharks-at-isla-contoy-mexico.title: Whale Sharks at Isla Contoy, Mexico
whale-sharks-at-isla-contoy-mexico.description: Whale sharks, the world's largest living species of fish, can be found in the waters that surround Isla Contoy throughout the Mexican wet season (June - September). These huge sharks are incredibly docile and harmless, they congregate in the area to feed on plankton that blooms at this time of year. Imagery collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

yongala-shipwreck-great-barrier-reef-a-w.title: Yongala Shipwreck, Great Barrier Reef - A World Heritage Marine Site
yongala-shipwreck-great-barrier-reef-a-w.description: The Yongala Shipwreck is a 110m former steel passenger and freight steamer which sank in 1911 during a tropical cyclone with 124 passengers onboard. The wreck lies at a depth of 33 metres and is constantly included on 'top 10 lists' for best dives in the world. The site has a strong current running over it which attracts a lot of marine life. Image collect XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

aquarius-reef-base-florida-keys-united-s.title: Aquarius Reef Base, Florida Keys - United States of America
aquarius-reef-base-florida-keys-united-s.description: The Florida International University manages the Aquarius Reefbase which is a fantastic underwater habitat utilized by marine biologists and astronauts for research and training purposes. In August 2014 the Catlin Seaview Survey team visited Aquarius whilst surveying the reefs around the Florida Keys. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

bleached-coral-at-airport-reef-american-.title: Bleached Coral at Airport Reef, American Samoa - During
bleached-coral-at-airport-reef-american-.description: These are the very first 360° images ever taken of a coral bleaching event and documenting the death of a reef due to climate change. They reveal the transition of a reef in American Samoa, from healthy in 2014, to bleached and then dead in 2015, during the 3rd Global Coral Bleaching Event. These events are a new phenomena caused by climate change and our rapidly warming oceans (93% of global warming heat is absorbed by the ocean). The first global event in 1998 killed an estimated 16% of the world's corals. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

dead-coral-at-airport-reef-american-samo.title: Dead Coral at Airport Reef, American Samoa - After
dead-coral-at-airport-reef-american-samo.description: These are the very first 360° images ever taken of a coral bleaching event and documenting the death of a reef due to climate change. They reveal the transition of a reef in American Samoa, from healthy in 2014, to bleached and then dead in 2015, during the 3rd Global Coral Bleaching Event. These events are a new phenomena caused by climate change and our rapidly warming oceans (93% of global warming heat is absorbed by the ocean). The first global event in 1998 killed an estimated 16% of the world's corals. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

ss-antilla-shipwreck-aruba.title: SS Antilla Shipwreck, Aruba
ss-antilla-shipwreck-aruba.description: The Antilla wreck is one of the largest shipwrecks in the Caribbean region, it rests intact in 60 feet of water off the north-western shores of Aruba in Malmok Bay. The wreck is covered in soft corals and tube sponges and provides habitat for countless marine creatures. No surprises that this wreck is a hit with scuba divers. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

ile-vache-marine-chagos-british-indian-o.title: Ile Vache Marine, Chagos, British Indian Ocean Territory
ile-vache-marine-chagos-british-indian-o.description: Ile Vache Marine is an island within the Chagos Archipelago (British Indian Ocean Territory), and is the site of a terrestrial restoration project. Under the surface, large expanses of the reef are dominated by metre wide table corals. Schools of blue and yellow fusiliers are found coasting over the reef in plentiful numbers. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

mayreau-hot-springs-st-vincent-the-grena.title: Mayreau Hot Springs, St Vincent & the Grenadines
mayreau-hot-springs-st-vincent-the-grena.description: This sheltered reef near the island of Mayreau is in the Tobago Cay Marine Park (TCMP). The park was established in 1997 to preserve the reefs that serve as a foraging ground and refuge for reef fish and juvenile turtles. The reef here is unique because it grows along an underwater hot spring. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

cozumel-mexico.title: Cozumel, Mexico
cozumel-mexico.description: Cozumel is the Mexican Caribbean’s largest island, about 20 kilometres off the eastern coast of the Yucatan Peninsula. Jacques Cousteau named it as one of the top 10 dive spots in the world, and it is certainly popular with scuba divers today. Dive in to explore the marine life and swim through a cloud of bubbles from a group of divers below. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

moresby-island-inside-chagos-british-ind.title: Moresby Island Inside, Chagos, British Indian Ocean Territory
moresby-island-inside-chagos-british-ind.description: This lagoonal reef is comprised of a high diversity of colourful and fragile foliose, plating, and branching corals, finding refuge on the inside of the atoll. On the dive, see if you can spot the stunning red-orange brain coral. Interspersed throughout the reef are floral-like carpet anemones, providing homes for the endemic Chagos anemonefish, Amphiprion chagosensis. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

pue-coral-gardens-cook-islands.title: PUE Coral Gardens, Cook Islands
pue-coral-gardens-cook-islands.description: In Pue Coral Garden, you will find a valley of large healthy porites coral bommies forming a seascape similar to a field of giant mushrooms. Keep your eyes peeled for a large Blue Triggerfish and a Hawksbill Turtle along this virtual dive. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

cheeca-rocks-florida-keys-usa.title: Cheeca Rocks, Florida Keys, USA
cheeca-rocks-florida-keys-usa.description: Cheeca Rocks, a small, well-developed patch reef, is another notable dive site in the Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary. Soft corals and large brain corals sit between patches of sand. The reef structure attracts plenty of fish and often turtles, too. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

freeport-grand-bahama.title: Freeport, Grand Bahama
freeport-grand-bahama.description: On this virtual dive you can find a discarded boat which has sunk to the sand on the ocean floor. Over time marine larvae could potentially drift over from nearby reefs and eventually settle on the boat, turning this ocean pollution into an artifical reef. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

jessie-beazley-reef-philippines.title: Jessie Beazley Reef, Philippines
jessie-beazley-reef-philippines.description: The UNESCO World Heritage listed Tubbataha Reefs Natural Park is the largest concentration of coral reefs in the Philippines. The park consists of three reef areas: North and South Atoll, divided by 8km, and Jessie Beazley Reef 20km to the north. The reef here is rich in corals and slopes to between 7-12 metres, finishing at a wall that drops off to over 50 metres. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

horseshoe-bay-bermuda.title: Horseshoe Bay, Bermuda
horseshoe-bay-bermuda.description: The coral reefs of Bermuda are the most northern massive coral reefs in the Atlantic Ocean. They are unique because they are dominated by brain corals, which usually only occupy 5-10% of the coral cover composition in Caribbean reefs. Take the virtual dive through Horseshoe Bay and have a look for yourself! Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

benwood-wreck-florida-keys-usa.title: Benwood Wreck, Florida Keys, USA
benwood-wreck-florida-keys-usa.description: The SS Benwood, a Norwegian merchant freighter, is located between Key Largo and French Reef in the Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary. It rests in less than 14 metres (45 feet) of water, which makes it a popular dive site. Take a look at the "ribs" of the ship in this virtual dive. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

jaco-island-timor-leste.title: Jaco Island, Timor Leste
jaco-island-timor-leste.description: Jaco Island is uninhabited by man, it's inhabited only by birds, so many birds that this tiny island has been recognised by Birdlife International as an 'Important Bird Area'. The waters around the island house exceptional coral reef cover and abundant fish life. This island and its reef sit within the protected boundary of the Nino Konis Santana National Park, East Timor's first National Park. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

lizard-island-great-barrier-reef.title: Lizard Island, Great Barrier Reef
lizard-island-great-barrier-reef.description: Lizard Island is found in the northern portion of the Great Barrier Reef. The small island is home to a luxury resort, a world-class research station which is operated by the Australian Museum, and a lot of large lizards. The area was badly affected by Tropical Cyclone Ita in 2014 - some of the damage is evident in this virtual dive. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

great-detached-reef-great-barrier-reef.title: Great Detached Reef, Great Barrier Reef
great-detached-reef-great-barrier-reef.description: The Great Detached Reef is a large complex of several reefs on an older fossil surface. The reef features the breathtaking walls and huge pelagic fish that the far-northern section of the Great Barrier Reef is famous for. Being so remote, this area is also home to plenty of big sharks which keep things interesting for divers. Image collect Catlin Seaview Survey.

shoal-bay-anguilla.title: Shoal Bay, Anguilla
shoal-bay-anguilla.description: Anguilla is a small island nation in the Caribbean Sea, 10 miles north of Saint Martin. The Shoal Bay Harbour Reef System is one of seven marine parks in the country. Take a virtual dive amongst the numerous sea fans. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

conch-reef-florida-keys-usa.title: Conch Reef, Florida Keys, USA
conch-reef-florida-keys-usa.description: Conch Reef is another reef protected by the Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary. The shallow, spur and groove reef formations support many species of marine life. Conch’s deep reef, which houses the Aquarius Underwater Laboratory, has been the focus of leading edge marine research for decades. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

klein-bonaire-bonaire.title: Klein Bonaire, Bonaire
klein-bonaire-bonaire.description: Klein Bonaire is an uninhabited islet off the west coast of Bonaire. The coral reefs here are under the protection of the Bonaire National Marine Park and are home to nesting grounds for three species of marine turtles: hawksbill, green and loggerhead. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

french-reef-restoration-area-florida-key.title: French Reef Restoration area, Florida Keys, USA
french-reef-restoration-area-florida-key.description: French Reef lies within the Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary (FKNMS), 11 kilometres (about 7 miles) southeast of Key Largo. This reef is one of several where elkhorn and staghorn corals grown in a coral nursery have been permitted for transplanting to aid in restoration efforts. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

eastpoint-curacao.title: Eastpoint, Curacao
eastpoint-curacao.description: This reef is situated at the very east of Curacao. There are lush gorgonians, together with hard corals and sponges. The prevailing eastern trade winds here bring nutrient rich water to help create a unique coral reef that provides a home to a variety of marine species. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

goffs-caye-belize.title: Goff's Caye, Belize
goffs-caye-belize.description: Goff’s Caye is an idyllic coral isle located right inside the UNESCO World Heritage listed Belize Barrier Reef, the largest barrier reef in the northern hemisphere. Take this virtual dive to experience some of the variety of corals in this area. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

the-channel-at-rose-atoll-american-samoa.title: The Channel at Rose Atoll, American Samoa
the-channel-at-rose-atoll-american-samoa.description: The Rose Atoll Marine National Monument is protected by the US Fish and Wildlife Service, and encompasses the Rose Atoll National Wildlife Refuge inside the lagoon. This virtual dive begins here, and moves through the channel to the ocean side of the reef crest, part of the National Marine Sanctuary of American Samoa. One of the most striking features of Rose Atoll is the pink hue of fringing reef caused by the dominance of coralline algae, which is the primary reef-building species. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

conception-reserve-bahamas.title: Conception Reserve, Bahamas
conception-reserve-bahamas.description: Conception Island has historical significance as one of the first landfalls of Columbus in the New World. The uninhabited island is located on a platform that rises out of the deep ocean 15 miles east of Santa Maria, Long Island. Under the water, there is an abundance of healthy coral and marine life. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

mantis-reef-great-barrier-reef-australia.title: Mantis Reef, Great Barrier Reef, Australia
mantis-reef-great-barrier-reef-australia.description: Mantis Reef is one of the jewels of the far northern UNESCO World Heritage listed Great Barrier Reef system. People travel a long way to dive in this area and they expect to see plenty of mega-fauna - big marine creatures. Mantis Reef is known as one of the best places to see silver-tip sharks! Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

black-rock-chimneys-cook-islands.title: Black Rock Chimneys, Cook Islands
black-rock-chimneys-cook-islands.description: Situated on the northwestern side of Rarotonga Island, this virtual dive is through a scenic and colorful landscape with sandy gullies and coral overhangs. The site gets its name from a nearby underwater rock formation which happens to be decorated in black corals. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

fagatele-bay-american-samoa.title: Fagatele Bay, American Samoa
fagatele-bay-american-samoa.description: Fagatele Bay is a 0.25 square mile (0.65 square km) coastal embayment that extends from Fagatele Point to Steps Point along the southwestern coast of Tutuila Island. This naturally protected bay was formed by a collapsed volcanic crater and is surrounded by steep, forested cliffs. Fagatele Bay was designated in 1986 as a National Marine Sanctuary site, in response to a proposal from the American Samoa Government to the NOAA Office of National Marine Sanctuaries. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

indonur-wreck-karimun-jawa-island-indone.title: Indonur Wreck, Karimun Jawa Island, Indonesia
indonur-wreck-karimun-jawa-island-indone.description: The Indonur, a Dutch steam ship, sank in 1963 after the Captain mistook a fire on the beach to be the lights of the Semarang and went full speed into the reef. The huge steel plates and riveted steam boilers now house all manner of reef fish and coral life, which grow bigger and bigger each year. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

jacques-cousteau-park-guadeloupe.title: Jacques Cousteau Park, Guadeloupe
jacques-cousteau-park-guadeloupe.description: The famous oceanographer Jacques Cousteau brought international attention to Pigeon Island in Guadeloupe by declaring it one of the world’s top diving areas. At the site is a bronze bust of the ocean explorer as a tribute. The shallow coral reefs here are great for snorkeling as well as scuba diving. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

penguin-reef-marovo-lagoon-solomon-islan.title: Penguin Reef, Marovo Lagoon, Solomon Islands
penguin-reef-marovo-lagoon-solomon-islan.description: At over 1,000 kilometres in length, Marovo Lagoon is the largest saltwater lagoon on the planet. It is a double barrier reef enclosed lagoon and has been proposed as a World Heritage site. One of the reefs here, Penguin Reef, is named not for its inhabitants, but for its discoverer, HMS Penguin, which came this way during wartime. Take a virtual dive to see the dense and spectacular coral growth. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

wishbone-reef-great-barrier-reef-austral.title: Wishbone Reef, Great Barrier Reef, Australia
wishbone-reef-great-barrier-reef-austral.description: Like many of the reefs in the far north of the UNESCO World Heritage Great Barrier Reef, Wishbone Reef is largely untouched by tourism due to its distance from port (it takes a long time to get here!). It's a beautiful reef which attracts all kinds of marine life. On this dive around the southern edge of the reef you will spot stunning corals, every colour of fish in the sea and even a shark or two. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

parrot-cay-turks-and-caicos.title: Parrot Cay, Turks and Caicos
parrot-cay-turks-and-caicos.description: Snorkelers enjoy the warm waters of Turks and Caicos. If you look closely, you will be able to spot our buddy diver with an underwater scooter. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

the-coral-nursery-florida-keys-usa.title: The Coral Nursery, Florida Keys, USA
the-coral-nursery-florida-keys-usa.description: Coral nurseries such as the one shown here are an emerging method for replenishing wild populations of corals in areas where there have been declines. Authorized by permits from Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary, corals may be attached to blocks, hung on line nurseries, or placed in baskets suspended off the seafloor. Marine biologists and volunteers monitor the growth and health of these coral colonies, and eventually transplant them back out onto the sanctuary’s reefs. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

molasses-reef-florida-keys-usa.title: Molasses Reef, Florida Keys, USA
molasses-reef-florida-keys-usa.description: Molasses Reef is the most popular scuba diving site in the Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary (which some suggest makes it one of the most heavily dived reefs in the world!). Along this virtual dive, you can see a circular brass object which is a high precision geodetic survey marker installed in 2004 at the site where coral habitat was restored after the Wellwood grounding. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

big-mushroom-coral-green-island-taiwan.title: Big Mushroom Coral, Green Island, Taiwan
big-mushroom-coral-green-island-taiwan.description: One of the most iconic dive sites in Taiwan is the world-famous “Big Mushroom” coral. With an estimated age of 1200 years, this Porites coral lays claim to being the oldest coral head in the world! It’s also pretty big, reaching 12 metres high with a circumference of 31 metres. Image collect by XL Catlin Seaview Survey.

outer-devils-crown-galapagos.title: Outer Devil's Crown, Galapagos
outer-devils-crown-galapagos.description: The Outer Devil's Crown is an underwater volcanic cone which provides habitat to lots of marine life. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey in partnership with Charles Darwin Foundation and Galapagos National Park.

trinta-reis.title: Trinta Reis
trinta-reis.description: Translating to "thirty kings", Trinta Reis is another spectacular dive in Fernando de Noronha which combines volcanic rock flows and white sandy bottoms. The vocanic rock structures provide habitat and protection for schooling fish, turtles and rays.

pedras-secas-1.title: Pedras Secas
pedras-secas-1.description: The more exposed of the Pedras Secas sites, a jagged volcanic rock formation breaks the surface of the ocean here and this is what gives the site it's name - Pedras Secas translates to "dry stones" in Portugese.

buraco-das-cabras.title: Buraco das Cabras
buraco-das-cabras.description: Buraco das Cabras is a 'drift dive' which means a diver is carried along by an ocean current rather than having to kick along in still water. Ocean currents carry nutrients through the ocean and so don't be surprised if you see plenty of marine life on this dive. Keep an eye out for a large green turtle but watch out for waves on the surface!

angel-fish-island.title: Angel Fish Island
angel-fish-island.description: A small, tranquil island off the eastern coast of Fernando de Noronha, Angel Fish Island's rocky shore provides refuge for all manner of marine life and another stunning dive site.

barretao.title: Barretao
barretao.description: This dive takes you into the shallow lagoon of Atol Das Rocas which is the only true atoll found in the South Atlantic Ocean. Inside the protected waters of the lagoon you will see large assemblages of fish and encrusting soft corals.

barretinha.title: Barretinha
barretinha.description: The Atol das Rocas region is recognised as a UNESCO World Heritage site and is a protected scientific reserve. At low tide the Rocas Atoll provides a spectacular seascape of lagoons and tidal pools teeming with fish, as the tide moves in so do the sharks, turtles and rays.

magic-point-at-maroubra-sydney-australia.title: Magic Point at Maroubra, Sydney, Australia
magic-point-at-maroubra-sydney-australia.description: The Grey Nurse Shark is the world's most menacing yet harmless shark. Although they grow to be rather large and have rows and rows of razor sharp teeth they're not considered dangerous to humans - they're rather docile. They breed off the coast of Maroubra and provide a real thrill for scuba divers. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

osprey-reef-coral-sea.title: Osprey Reef, Coral Sea
osprey-reef-coral-sea.description: Technically, Osprey is not part of the Great Barrier Reef; it's found in the Coral Sea about 100km outside of the reef, an overnight trip for most dive boats. Osprey Reef is a submerged atoll, it's part of the Northwestern Group of the Coral Sea Islands. Its remote location makes this a very special area; vertical reef walls, which rise from a depth of 2000m, are home to a dwarf form of Nautilus pompilius that are found no-where else. One of the world's smallest fish, Schindleria brevipingius, is found in the Osprey Reef lagoon but it is the big fish that make the trip worthwhile. Sharks, and lots of them! Image collect Catlin Seaview Survey.

manlys-fairy-bower-sydney-australia.title: Manly's Fairy Bower, Sydney, Australia
manlys-fairy-bower-sydney-australia.description: Manly is another famous Sydney beach (this one is on the northern side of the Harbour) with a great underwater environment. The Fairy Bower sits between Manly Beach and North Head, and it's a great place to see Dusky Whaler sharks. Image collect Catlin Seaview Survey.

knife-reef-great-barrier-reef.title: Knife Reef, Great Barrier Reef
knife-reef-great-barrier-reef.description: Knife Reef is located northeast of Townsville on the outer Great Barrier Reef. The reef here is only about 2km in length and is covered in some impressive coral growth, however there is also a fair amount of coral rubble in the area - it's unclear if this is due to storm activity or other factors.  Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

the-cod-hole-great-barrier-reef.title: The Cod Hole, Great Barrier Reef
the-cod-hole-great-barrier-reef.description: The Cod Hole was one of the first ever protected sites on the Great Barrier Reef thanks largely to the efforts of Ron and Valerie Taylor, who in the early 1980's witnessed the huge cod population decimated by overfishing. This reef attracts a large variety of marine life aside from the resident Potato Cods, including big Coral Trout, all varieties of shark, Minke Whales, dolphins and thousands of coral reef fish. See what else you can spot in this virtual dive on this truly world class dive site. Image collect Catlin Seaview Survey.

st-crispins-reef-great-barrier-reef.title: St. Crispins Reef, Great Barrier Reef
st-crispins-reef-great-barrier-reef.description: St. Crispins Reef sits between two of the more heavily visited reefs in the area (Agincourt and Opal) and is a great dive site for avoiding the crowds in the area. The reef here is varied and healthy and home to more of the fantastic marine life that one would expect to find on the Great Barrier Reef. Image collect Catlin Seaview Survey.

myrmidon-reef-great-barrier-reef.title: Myrmidon Reef, Great Barrier Reef
myrmidon-reef-great-barrier-reef.description: In Greek Mythology the Myrmidons were Achilles' fierce and loyal warriors. Perhaps it is the enduring and ancient nature of this reef that led to its name. The reef itself is a Marine Park Green Zone so the area is protected from fishing, this means that there are plenty of large fish to dive with. The Green Zone however can't protect the area from rough weather, over the past 10 years this reef has been particularly affected by cyclone activity meaning reef structures are quite patchy in places. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

norman-reef-great-barrier-reef.title: Norman Reef, Great Barrier Reef
norman-reef-great-barrier-reef.description: Norman Reef is only a few miles from the deep continental shelf. One of the larger dive operators in the area has a pontoon and a submersible stationed permanently on the reef which can be visited by hundreds of people each day. The reef structure here is varied and interesting for both snorkelers and scuba divers, it's very healthy and home to a huge variety of marine life. Image collect Catlin Seaview Survey.

tijou-reef-great-barrier-reef.title: Tijou Reef, Great Barrier Reef
tijou-reef-great-barrier-reef.description: Tijou reef has many excellent dive sites; healthy coral gardens on the protected side, wall diving on the eastern side and plenty of sharks around the northern tip of the reef. Silvertip Sharks, Whitetip Reef Sharks and Grey Reef Sharks are known to frequent this area and give divers a thrill. Image collect Catlin Seaview Survey.

ribbon-reef-10-great-barrier-reef.title: Ribbon Reef 10, Great Barrier Reef
ribbon-reef-10-great-barrier-reef.description: The Ribbon Reefs stretch over 100km of the outer Great Barrier Reef. Each reef is separated from the next by a channel; some are very deep, some are quite shallow. The channel between Ribbon Reef No.9 and No.10 is one of the deeper ones and as a result is brimming with life. Image collect Catlin Seaview Survey.

underwater-museum-isla-mujeres.title: Underwater Museum, Isla Mujeres
underwater-museum-isla-mujeres.description: In 2009 Jason deCaires Taylor began placing his pH neutral sculptures onto the seafloor of Isla Mujeres and Cancun which is now known as the Cancun Underwater Museum. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

north-broken-passage-great-barrier-reef.title: North Broken Passage, Great Barrier Reef
north-broken-passage-great-barrier-reef.description: The North Broken Passage is a channel through an unnamed reef in the Cape Melville area. Coral reefs are full of life, but many of the fish that live on the reef are small. It's channels, like the North Broken Passage, are home to the larger pelagic and predatorial fish. Image collect Catlin Seaview Survey.

opal-reef-great-barrier-reef.title: Opal Reef, Great Barrier Reef
opal-reef-great-barrier-reef.description: The Opal Reef is a true gem, especially when it comes to corals. Both the hard and soft corals on this reef are breathtaking. The area is also home to large marine life, most notably a very friendly Maori Wrasse. Image collect Catlin Seaview Survey.

bare-island-at-botany-bay-sydney-austral.title: Bare Island at Botany Bay, Sydney, Australia
bare-island-at-botany-bay-sydney-austral.description: Botany Bay was the site of Captain James Cook's first landing of the HMS Endeavour on the continent of Australia in 1770. They called the site "Stingray Bay" originally as the area was so full of the creatures. Bare Island is found on the northern edge of Botany Bay - while you won't find any stingrays on this virtual dive you might be able to spot a tiny, bright nudibranch. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

christ-of-the-abyss-florida-keys.title: Christ of the Abyss, Florida Keys
christ-of-the-abyss-florida-keys.description: There are 3 "Christ of the Abyss" statues currently residing beneath the surface of the sea. This "American Christ" is the third and most recent in the set of bronze statues. It's located in the waters off Key Largo, Florida and was cast from the same mould as the original statue. Florida's "Christ of the Abyss" weighs 260kg but is secured to 9 tons of concrete - it's been here since 1965. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

coral-restoration-nursery-florida-keys-u.title: Coral Restoration Nursery, Florida Keys - United States of America
coral-restoration-nursery-florida-keys-u.description: The Coral Restoration Foundation grows endangered staghorn coral at the Snapper Ledge Coral Nursery located off Tavernier Key in Florida. Imagery captured by Catlin Seaview Survey, NOAA/ONMS and the Florida Keys Natl. Marine Sanctuary

tubbataha-reefs-natural-park-philippines.title: Tubbataha Reefs Natural Park, Philippines - A World Heritage Marine Site
tubbataha-reefs-natural-park-philippines.description: Tubbataha Reefs Natural Park was added to the UNESCO World Heritage list in 1993, it lies in the middle of the Sulu Sea and is one of the Philippines’ oldest ecosystems. The region contains excellent examples of pristine reef with an incredibly high diversity of marine life. The area supports 374 species of corals, (that's almost 90% of all coral species in the Philippines!). The area also supports 11 species of cetaceans, 11 species of sharks, and an estimated 479 species of fish. This image collect focuses on the North Atoll and was completed by the Catlin Seaview Survey.

agincourt-reef-great-barrier-reef.title: Agincourt Reef, Great Barrier Reef
agincourt-reef-great-barrier-reef.description: The reef at Agincourt is so impressive that there is a weather station, a helicopter landing platform, a permanent pontoon for divers and snorklers and an underwater observatory located there. The Catlin Seaview Survey team visited the site as part of the 2012 Great Barrier Reef expedition work.

saunders-reef-great-barrier-reef.title: Saunders Reef, Great Barrier Reef
saunders-reef-great-barrier-reef.description: Found at the far-north of the Great Barrier Reef chain is a rarely visited site called Saunders Reef. Because this reef is so isolated, the area is full of life. All kinds of pelagics and every colour of reef fish imaginable can be seen along with sharks, dolphins and turtles. Image collect Catlin Seaview Survey.

belize-barrier-reef-reserve-system-beliz.title: Belize Barrier Reef Reserve System, Belize - A World Heritage Marine Site
belize-barrier-reef-reserve-system-beliz.description: The largest barrier reef in the northern hemisphere, UNESCO added this site to the World Heritage in danger list in 2009. The system illustrates a classic example of reef types through fringing, barrier and atoll, and the regions seven sites provide a significant habitat for threatened species. This particular dive features Half Moon Cay, at the southern end of Lighthouse Reef Atoll. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

camp-cove-sydney-australia.title: Camp Cove, Sydney, Australia
camp-cove-sydney-australia.description: Camp Cove is often the first place people learn to dive in Sydney. A gentle shore entry leads out into a rocky wall that is home to some of Sydney Harbour's strangest marine creatures. See what you can find on this virtual dive. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

sian-kaan-mexico-a-world-heritage-marine.title: Sian Ka'an, Mexico- A World Heritage Marine Site
sian-kaan-mexico-a-world-heritage-marine.description: Sian Ka'an is a biosphere reserve which extends from the east coast of Mexico out into the Caribbean Sea. Home to some 80 recorded species of reef-building corals, the portion of the Mesoamerican Reef within the reserve is one of the most bio-diverse in Mexico. Jointly with neighbouring aquatic habitats it harbours more than 400 species of fish and a wealth of other marine life. For this reason it was named as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1987. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

lady-elliot-island-great-barrier-reef.title: Lady Elliot Island, Great Barrier Reef
lady-elliot-island-great-barrier-reef.description: This is the southernmost coral cay of the Great Barrier Reef, and features a diver encountering a manta ray. It is in the green zone, which is offered the highest protection by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

wilson-island-great-barrier-reef.title: Wilson Island, Great Barrier Reef
wilson-island-great-barrier-reef.description: Wilson Island is an important turtle and bird rookery fringed by a white coral beach and covered with pisonia forest. From November to March, the island is home to wedge-tailed shearwaters and green turtles; from June to September, humpback whales can be seen going to and from their winter feeding grounds. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

apo-island-philippines.title: Apo Island, Philippines
apo-island-philippines.description: Apo Island is a volcanic island which is surrounded by a marine reserve. At present, the island is home to over 650 documented species of fish and estimated to have over 400 species of corals. Most of the Philippines' 450 species of coral can be found here, from tiny bubble corals to huge gorgonian sea fans and brain corals. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

hanuma-bay-hawaii.title: Hanuma Bay, Hawaii
hanuma-bay-hawaii.description: It is a marine embayment formed within a volcanic cone and located along the southeast coast of the Island of Oʻahu (just east of Honolulu) in the Hawaiian Islands. Hanauma is one of the most popular tourist destinations on the Island and has suffered somewhat from overuse. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

molokini-crater-hawaii.title: Molokini Crater, Hawaii
molokini-crater-hawaii.description: Molokini is a crescent-shaped, partially submerged volcanic crater which forms a small islet located in Alalakeiki Channel between the islands of Maui and Kahoʻolawe. It is one of the top 10 dive spots in the world. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

columbia-deep-mexico.title: Columbia Deep, Mexico
columbia-deep-mexico.description: Another great dive site just off the island of Cozumel, on Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula. Keep an eye out for a big Hawksbill turtle.  Imagery collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

roche-saint-nicholas-monaco.title: Roche Saint Nicholas, Monaco
roche-saint-nicholas-monaco.description: Roche Saint Nicholas lies at the feet of the iconic Oceanographic Museum of Monaco. The museum was established by Prince Albert I in 1910 and later managed by the most famous underwater explorer of them all, Jacques Yves Cousteau. Imagery collect by Catlin Seaview Survey in partnership with Oceanographic Museum of Monaco and Prince Albert II Foundation.

larvotto-marine-reserve-monaco.title: Larvotto Marine Reserve, Monaco
larvotto-marine-reserve-monaco.description: Larvotto Marine Reserve is a protected area in the Mediterranean off the coast of Monaco. Imagery collect by Catlin Seaview Survey in partnership with Oceanographic Museum of Monaco and Prince Albert II Foundation.

santa-rosa-wall-mexico.title: Santa Rosa Wall, Mexico
santa-rosa-wall-mexico.description: One of the more popular recreational dive sites in the Cozumel area due to it's great structure that rises from the deep. Look out for the overhangs in this dive. Imagery collected by Catlin Seaview Survey.

hourglass-reef-bermuda.title: Hourglass Reef, Bermuda
hourglass-reef-bermuda.description: Hourglass reef has nice large breakers teeming with fish life. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

mary-celeste-wreck-bermuda.title: Mary Celeste Wreck, Bermuda
mary-celeste-wreck-bermuda.description: The Mary Celeste was a paddle steamer which sunk in 1864 after being used to run ammunitions and supplies to the Confederate forces during the American Civil War. The wreck sits in 55 feet of water and one of the huge paddle wheels is still clearly visible at the dive site.  Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

north-east-breaker-bermuda.title: North East Breaker, Bermuda
north-east-breaker-bermuda.description: The Northeast Breaker dive site is actually made up of over a dozen separate breakers, each with its own highlights. A great shallow dive site. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

south-west-breaker-bermuda.title: South West Breaker, Bermuda
south-west-breaker-bermuda.description: The southern-most breaking reef in Bermuda is not a coral or rock formation but made from fossilized prehistoric worms. The structure is incredibly strong and can easily withstand the strong winter storms. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey.

champion-island-west-galapagos.title: Champion Island West, Galapagos
champion-island-west-galapagos.description: Swim with schools of fish around Isla Campion, Galapagos Islands. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey in partnership with Charles Darwin Foundation and Galapagos National Park.

gordons-rocks-galapagos.title: Gordon's Rocks, Galapagos
gordons-rocks-galapagos.description: These steep underwater sea mountains provide habitat for a huge variety of marine life. Strong currents make this site suitable for advanced divers only. Image collect by Catlin Seaview Survey in partnership with Charles Darwin Foundation and Galapagos National Park.

tydeman-reef-great-barrier-reef.title: Tydeman Reef, Great Barrier Reef
tydeman-reef-great-barrier-reef.description: Tydeman Reef is found well inside the Great Barrier Reef system and not too far from the Australian land-mass at Cape Melville. The location of Tydeman means that the reef is very protected from the weather systems that can batter the more exposed reefs. Image collect Catlin Seaview Survey.

pedras-secas.title: Pedras Secas
pedras-secas.description: Pedras Secas is one of the iconic dive sites of Fernando de Noronha. It's an impressive dive site that attracts a lot of marine life. The volcanic rocks provide an arena-like formation that is surrounded by passages, holes, caverns, an iconic main arch and a 60 foot 'swim through' tunnel.

parent.title: Oceans
parent.description: Oceans cover 71% of the Earth's surface and only 5% of the world's oceans have been explored. Imagery collected by The Ocean Agency, Underwater Earth, and XL Catlin Seaview Survey.
